Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: Developing Low-Carbon Cities in the US, China, and India Through Integration Across Engineering, Environmental Sciences, Social Sciences, and Public Health
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Partnership for International Research and Education (PIRE) award supports a five-year project that brings researchers and students from six U.S. institutions together with five partner institutions in India and three in China to conduct transformative research that will contribute to the development of low-carbon, sustainable cities in the U.S., India, and China. There is a need for cities to have science-based tools to model present-day greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with cities, and to project future GHG emissions reductions resulting from a combination of technology and policy strategies. This research effort is two-pronged, focusing on reducing greenhouse gas emissions in selected cities and also addressing broader sustainability goals such as economic development, water scarcity, environmental pollution, climate change, and public health. Principal Investigator Anu Ramaswami, University of Minnesota and colleagues from Yale University (Marian Chertow), Georgia Institute of Technology (Armistead Russell), National Center for Atmospheric Research (Patricia Romero-Lankao), University of Colorado Denver (Christopher Weible), and the National Academy of Engineering Center for Engineering, Ethics & Society (Rachelle Hollander) will collaborate with partners at TERI University, the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Tongji University, Tsinghua University, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute for the Urban Environment, and several Non-Governmental Organizations in India and China.

PIRE research explores transformations needed in coupled technological, infrastructural, and social sub-systems that can help urban areas realize low-carbon, resource-efficient outcomes leading to sustainable cities. This project targets Asian cities in transition. These are small rapidly industrializing cities in Asia with populations less than 1M that are expected to dominate future urbanization. The investigators will compare their development trajectories with those of megacities having populations greater than 10M and smaller service-economy cities in the U.S., thus providing a road-map for sustainable development in different city types worldwide. The research team will evaluate unique infrastructure interventions in smaller Asian cities --urban industrial symbiosis, early transportation planning incorporating bus rapid transit, and electric power sector planning under water-scarcity conditions-- that can achieve the multiple sustainability goals listed above. Social science research will explore the extent to which local water-supply and public health concerns can motivate the adoption of low-carbon infrastructures, and will identify the most effective political and institutional interventions that could facilitate their adoption in different city types. The interactions between infrastructures, social actors and sustainability outcomes will be evaluated together using a novel inter-disciplinary Social-Ecological-Infrastructural Systems (SEIS) framework.

PIRE education will develop a first-of-its-kind International Summer School and MS Program on Sustainable Infrastructure-Sustainable Cities for graduate students in three nations drawn from six major disciplines: Engineering, Environmental Sciences, Industrial Ecology, Urban Planning, Public Affairs and Public Health. Curriculum and fieldwork will nurture multiple competencies addressing: inter-cultural learning, inter-disciplinary skills, sustainability knowledge, systems-integration, community-based practices, and awareness of ethics in global discussions of sustainability.

The intellectual merit of this project is that it integrates for the first time six diverse disciplines both in research and education using a science-based systems framework. Cross-disciplinary integration, urban-to-global linkages, integration of urban infrastructures with public health and governance, and international cross-city comparisons, taken together will advance the science of low-carbon cities.

As to broader impacts, this PIRE will directly affect close to 100 students across three nations, benefit residents in the fieldwork cities, and create long-term capacity to translate research to sustainability in communities and potentially worldwide. Partnerships with the U.S. National Academy of Engineering Center for Engineering, Ethics & Society and the Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute for the Urban Environment enable the dissemination of research and education outputs, while work with NGOs such as ICLEI-Local Governments for Sustainability (South Asia), Urban Health Resource Centre (UHRC), and Resource Optimization Initiative (ROI) will help translate research into action in communities. The project is funded by NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE) through the PIRE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to develop a transformative interdisciplinary research and education program aimed at developing low carbon and sustainable cities in the US, India, and China, comparing cities of different typologies in these three countries which, together contribute >50% of global carbon emissions. The overarching goal was to advance an interdisciplinary framework that explores the nexus between global carbon mitigation goals and local sustainability priorities like waste management, clean energy, air pollution, and health, both from the science and policy perspective. This was accomplished by fostering international research and education across 11 US and international partner institutions. US institutions included: the University of Minnesota, Yale University, the Georgia Institute of Technology, the University of Colorado Denver, the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research, and the Center for Engineering Ethics & Society at the National Academy of Engineering. International partners in China and India included: Tsinghua University, the Chinese Academy of Sciences, the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, ICLEI South Asia, and the Resource Optimization Initiative (India).

SPECIFIC RESEARCH GOALS included advancing a social-ecological-infrastructure framework for studying low-carbon development in core infrastructure sectors in cities in the US, India, and China, collating information across all three nations, and working with policy partners to advance comparative study. SPECIFIC EDUCATION AND TRAINING GOALS included: a) providing opportunities for graduate students to build cross-country knowledge and long-term collaborations, b) increase intercultural awareness, and c) advance infrastructure systems thinking and ethics in urban sustainability education. SPECIFIC OUTREACH GOALS included exhanging knowledge with external partners and policy officials in the US, India, and China through deep engagement.

Major research advances (both in methodology and findings) were made on the following broad topics:

  • Transboundary assessment of seven key infrastructure sectors- energy, buildings, waste, water, transportation, green space, and food systems
  • Understanding greenhouse gas emissions from the use of all the above infrastructure sectors in US, Indian, and Chinese cities
  • Assessing overarching relationships between emissions and health across infrastructure sectors
  • Understanding material use and embodied energy in infrastructure
  • Identifying waste burning as key source of air pollution in Indian cities
  • Assessment of climate extremes and health, including social vulnerability assessment
  • Sector-specific socio-technical analysis of solutions
  • Methods for assessing industrial symbiosis in cities
  • Understanding of sustainability coalitions through media analysis
  • Overarching review of policy solutions for low-carbon cities in US, India, and China

The research led to high-impact publications in journals including: Science, Nature Climate Change, Journal of Industrial Ecology, Journal of Cleaner Production, Global Environmental Change, Environmental Science & Technology, Environmental Research Letters, among others. In all, more than 40 peer-reviewed publications were generated, many of which were co-authored with international research partners.

A key focus of this PIRE was to build relationships between science and policy communities around the topic of low carbon infrastructure development in cities. Science-policy partnerships were formed with high-level organizations including UN Environment and ICLEI-South Asia. Principal Investigator Anu Ramswami continues to be a member of the International Resource Panel, hosted by UN Environment, which provides a high-level outlet for research findings generated through this PIRE.

Research findings from this PIRE were presented at dozens of conferences over the course of the project, including high-level science-policy conferences such as the IPCC Cities and Climate Change conference, as well as the 2018 World Urban Forum hosted by UN Habitat.

The project has led to the development of impressive data resources, including a comprehensive database on industry and infrastructure in 637 Chinese cities. The project team continues to work to develop and expand this powerful database to include cities in the US and India.

The project made educational advances hosting international winter and summer schools bringing together graduate students from the US, China, and India. The project also created opportunities for international faculty exchanges hosted by US institutions. In research training, the project supported graduate research assistantship and post-doctoral positions. These positions provided valuable technical research experience, opportunities to engage with research partners in India and China, and opportunities to engage with policy-making communities. 

Research, education, and policy-engagement highlights from the project include:

  • International winter and summer schools
  • A workshop hosted by the Center for Engineering Ethics and Society of the National Academy of Engineering
  • An article on international, interdisciplinary education on sustainable infrastructure and cities published in The Bridge
  • A commentary article on meta-principles for smart cities published in Science
  • A series of high-impact research articles on waste burning in India that generated media coverage from the Wall Street Journal, the Times of India, and Hindi language newspapers, later playing a role in policy development  
  • A series of high-impact research articles advancing new methods for industrial symbiosis in cities in China   
  • A research article leveraging a PIRE dataset on 637 Chinese cities published in the journal Nature Climate Change
  • A commentary article published in the UN Environment publication Our Planet
